name: Salt Typhoon - Rapid7 August 2025 Report
description: ATT&CK Navigator heatmap for Salt Typhoon (Earth Estries / GhostEmperor / FamousSparrow / UNC2286) based on Rapid7 Labs Threat Focus report, August 2025. Scoring: 3 = Core/Critical, 2 = Frequently Used, 1 = Supporting.

techniques.comment: Primary initial access vector. Exploits unpatched VPN appliances (Ivanti), firewalls (Fortinet, Sophos), Exchange servers (ProxyLogon), and network edge devices via zero-day or N-day exploits.
Maintains stolen VPN credentials for recurrent access. Leaked data showed hundreds of router usernames/passwords. Also used for persistence and lateral movement.
Stolen VPN credentials and compromised accounts maintained for persistent access.
Pivots through VPN/RDP using stolen credentials to access additional systems.
Uses PowerShell and batch scripts for payload deployment. WMIC used for spawning processes remotely, enumerating system info, and dumping user accounts.
PowerShell explicitly cited for payload deployment and scripting.
Batch scripts used for payload deployment.
WMIC (Windows Management Instrumentation) explicitly named as a key tool for remote process execution, system enumeration, and account dumping.
Scheduled tasks used for execution and persistence. Report mentions unexpected creation of scheduled tasks as a detection indicator.
Scheduled tasks for maintaining persistence.

CRITICAL - Demodex kernel-mode rootkit is a signature Salt Typhoon tool. Hides processes and files at the kernel level, maintains SYSTEM-level control undetected. Loaded via exploit bypassing driver signature enforcement.
Kernel-mode rootkits (Demodex) maintain stealthy persistence. Custom backdoors (SparrowDoor) installed as Windows services that start on boot.
SparrowDoor installed as a Windows service for persistence. Backdoors deployed as services. Detection: monitor for unexpected creation of new services.
Creates new local accounts for recurrent access. Report explicitly recommends auditing for unauthorized account creation.
Exploits system vulnerabilities for privilege gain, including known Windows privilege escalation flaws. Demodex rootkit uses driver exploits for kernel-level privileges.
DLL sideloading explicitly mentioned as a privilege escalation technique.
DLL sideloading for privilege escalation.
DLL sideloading also used for defense evasion - loading malicious payloads through legitimate binaries.
DLL sideloading for defense evasion.
Abuse of access tokens or credential material to assume higher privileges.
Heavy obfuscation and encryption in malware. Demodex and other implants use multiple layers of encryption/packing. Multi-stage loaders for in-memory execution.
Deletes or alters logs to cover tracks. Anti-forensic techniques employed throughout operations.
Uses valid code-signing certificates and known benign binaries (LOLBins) to execute malicious payloads. Blends malicious activity with normal sysadmin behavior.
Disables security tools or uses kernel hooks to blind endpoint defenses.
Demodex rootkit loaded via exploit that bypasses driver signature enforcement.
Core credential access technique. Mimikatz explicitly observed for LSASS memory dumping to extract plaintext passwords, hashes, and Kerberos tickets. Enables lateral movement via pass-the-hash.
LSASS memory dumping via Mimikatz - explicitly cited as core credential access method.
Leaked data showed hundreds of router passwords obtained from configuration files. Steals password files and router config credentials.
Pass-the-hash using harvested password hashes/tokens for lateral movement.
Keylogging/input capture on compromised servers. SNAPPYBEE RAT provides keylogging capability. Cobalt Strike also includes keylogging.
Reconnaissance of domain trusts and accounts. Enumerates running services, processes, and security software.
Domain trust discovery for understanding network architecture and lateral movement paths.
Network scanning and mapping of connected networks and devices.
Enumerates running services and processes on penetrated systems.
Gathers info on data repositories - database listings, file shares.
Enumerates security software on penetrated systems to understand defensive posture.
Primary lateral movement method. PsExec and SMB/WMI for remote command execution. RDP with stolen credentials. Explicitly named tools: PsExec, WMIC.
SMB/Windows Admin Shares via PsExec - primary lateral movement tool.
RDP with stolen credentials for lateral movement.
Deploys malware to multiple systems using enterprise software deployment tools or domain admin access.
JumbledPath sniffer backdoor deployed at network choke points to capture traffic in real-time. Monitors network traffic via implanted packet capture tools.
Collects sensitive data from local systems: database dumps, email archives, telecom CDRs, voice intercepts, configuration files, network diagrams.
Targets Exchange email servers. Email archives explicitly listed as collected data. Exchange exploitation (ProxyLogon) was a key initial access vector.
Uses utilities like robocopy or custom scripts to gather files of interest. Automated/scripted data gathering.
Stages collected files before exfiltration. Files staged in password-protected archives for exfil.
Stages collected files in password-protected archives for exfiltration.
Core C2 method. Encrypted C2 channels using HTTP/HTTPS. GhostSpider uses TLS-encrypted communications. Cobalt Strike beacons mimic web traffic. Traffic over common ports (443) to blend in.
HTTPS C2 - primary command and control protocol. GhostSpider and Cobalt Strike both use HTTPS.
Utilizes compromised servers or cloud services as relay/proxy nodes for C2.
Encrypted C2 channels. GhostSpider uses TLS encryption. Cobalt Strike beacons use encrypted channels. Multiple layers of encryption observed.
Frequently rotates C2 infrastructure and domains to avoid tracking.
Primary exfiltration method. Data exfiltrated over encrypted channels camouflaged as normal HTTPS traffic. Telecom data transmitted gradually to avoid detection.
Uploads stolen data to cloud storage services or attacker-controlled servers. Secondary exfiltration method.
Exfiltration over alternative protocols including DNS channels mentioned alongside HTTPS.

metadata.name: Source
metadata.value: Rapid7 Labs - Threat Focus: Salt Typhoon, August 2025

metadata.value: Salt Typhoon (Earth Estries / GhostEmperor / FamousSparrow / UNC2286)
